Authors: Sandra Hilário, Liliana Santos, Artur Alves
Title:
Diversity and Pathogenicity of Diaporthe Species Revealed
from a Survey of Blueberry Orchards in Portugal
Keywords:
Diaporthaceae, dieback, twig blight, pathogens, phylogeny,
Vaccinium corymbosum
Abstract:
Blueberries (Vaccinium corymbosum) are widely cultivated
worldwide and largely consumed due to their known antioxidant and
medicinal properties. Although Diaporthe species have been recorded in
Portugal as causal agents of blueberry twig blight and dieback, there is
still scarce information on the species able to cause these symptoms.
Therefore, in the present study, the distribution and diversity of
Diaporthe species associated with diseased blueberry plants was assessed
through a nation survey. A multilocus sequence analysis of the rDNA
internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region, the translation elongation
factor 1-alpha (tef1-α), β-tubulin (tub2), calmodulin (cal) and histone
3 (his3) genes revealed the presence of the species Diaporthe ambigua,
D. amygdali, D. foeniculina, D. rudis, D. leucospermi, D. malorum, D.
crousii and Diaporthe ×hybrida. Moreover, all the species were fully
characterized based on a detailed morphological description. This study
is the first to report D. leucospermi, D. malorum, D. amygdali and
Diaporthe ×hybrida on diseased blueberries in Portugal, whose
pathogenicity to this host is not fully understood. Our results have
also shown that D. vaccinii might be a minor pathogen on blueberry
plants. The current study improves our understanding of species causing
dieback and twig blight on Portuguese blueberry orchards and provides
useful information to stakeholders involved in the production of these
berries.
